metadata.case_name: S. G. Jaisinghani v. Union of India & Ors.

facts.text: Government of India, on September 29, 1944, reconstituted Income-Tax Services as Class I (Grade I and II) and Class II (Grade III). Recruitment to Class I Grade II: 80% direct recruitment through competitive examination, 20% promotion from Class II Grade III.

Rules of seniority laid down in Government of India, Ministry of Finance, Revenue Division letter dated January 24, 1950 (Ex. G). Principles for seniority: between direct recruits, between promotees, between direct recruits completing probation and promotees in same year.

Seniority rules revised on September 5, 1952 by letter No. F. No. 58(3)-Ad.IT/50. Rule 1(f)(iii): Promotees recommended by Departmental Promotion Committee senior to direct recruits appointed in calendar year of meeting and three previous years. Rule 1(f)(iv): Class II officer passing departmental exam before appointment to Class I via competitive exam deemed promotee.
Recruitment quotas revised October 18, 1951: 66-2/3% direct recruitment, 33-1/3% promotion from Class II Grade III for five years; surplus promotion vacancies to direct quota.

Direct recruits to Class I Grade II on two-year probation, including training and departmental exam. Minimum five years service (including probation) before consideration for promotion to Class I Grade I.

Rule 4 of Rules of Promotions (Central Board of Revenue Office Procedure Manual): Promotions to Class I Grade I from Grade II on seniority-cum-fitness, minimum five years gazetted service including one year in Class I Grade II.

Appellant S. G. Jaisinghani filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Punjab High Court (Civil Writ No. 189-D of 1962) challenging seniority rule and quota implementation as violating Arts. 14 and 16(1). High Court dismissed on March 11, 1964.

Appellant successful in competitive exam 1950, joined Class I Grade II in 1951. Respondents 4,5,6 appointed Class II Grade III in 1947, successful in 1950 exam, deemed promotees under Rule 1(f)(iv), senior to appellant.
Excess promotees: Appellant alleged 71 excess 1951-1956; High Court found 31 excess 1951-1954. Affidavit by Mr. R.C. Dutt (Jan 31, 1967) provided recruitment figures but not vacancies.
Formative years 1945-1950: Re-organization ongoing, quota not strictly applied.
Writ Petition No. 5 of 1966 under Art. 32 by another petitioner raising similar issues.

legal_issues.text: Whether rule 1(f)(iii) of 1952 seniority rules violates Arts. 14 and 16(1) by giving promotees seniority over direct recruits of same year and three previous years.
Whether promotion rule from Class I Grade II to Grade I (Rule 4) discriminatory, as promotees count Class II service towards minimum five years.
Whether rule 1(f)(iv) deeming certain direct recruits as promotees for seniority violates Arts. 14 and 16(1).
Whether quota rule (66-2/3% direct, 33-1/3% promotees) binding, and excess promotees 1951-1956 illegal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Seniority rule 1(f)(iii) creates unjustifiable classification post-entry into Class I Grade II, pushing down direct recruits and violating Arts. 14, 16(1). All in Grade II one class, no sub-classification.
Promotion rule discriminatory: Direct recruits need 5 years in Grade II; promotees only 1 year in Grade II + 4 in Class II.
Rule 1(f)(iv) artificially seniors deemed promotees over direct recruits from same exam.
Excessive promotee recruitment violates quota rule (71 excess 1951-1956).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Income-tax Officers (Class 1, Grade II) Service Recruitment Rules 3,4

respondent_arguments.text: Seniority rule reasonable: Recruitment from two sources; promotees have experience (min 5 years Class II), direct recruits only 2-year probation. Selection on merit, stiff standards.
Quota mere policy/administrative direction, not statutory, no justiciable breach. Substantial compliance.
Promotion rule carries out seniority policy; ignoring Class II service nullifies seniority weightage.
Deemed promotees under 1(f)(iv) have 5 years Class II by 1952; would be senior anyway via 1(f)(iii); incentivizes competition.

court_reasoning.text: Not classification within one service but adjustment of seniority from two sources. Promotees have experience equivalent to direct recruits' probation + 3 years work. Rule reasonable with quota limit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Seniority gives weightage to promotees' 3 years outstanding Class II work equated to 2 years probation.

court_reasoning.text: Promotion rule linked to seniority; counting Class II service prevents junior direct recruits leapfrogging seniors. No discrimination.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rule prevents nullification of seniority weightage.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 1(f)(iv) reasonable: Deemed promotees have prior service; would be senior anyway; provides incentive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Avoids demotion relative to Class II juniors.

court_reasoning.text: Quota fixed under statutory Rule 4, binding. No discretion to deviate yearly. Excess promotees illegal; linked to seniority validity. Mandamus to readjust seniority post-quota compliance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Quota rule integral to reasonableness of seniority.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 16(1) covers promotion, salary, etc., as matters relating to employment. Reasonable classification permitted if sources differ rationally.

holdings.text: Seniority rules 1(f)(iii) and (iv) valid, not violating Arts. 14, 16(1).
Quota rule binding under Recruitment Rule 4; excess promotees 1951-56+ illegal.
Mandamus to readjust seniority after quota compliance; not affecting permanent Asst. Commissioners.

precedents_cited.case_name: General Manager, Southern Railway v. Rangachari
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 16(1) covers matters relating to employment including promotion; reasonable classification allowed.
Rule of law opposes unlimited discretion.
Discretion guided by law, not arbitrary.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Guarantee of equality; challenged rules held valid except linked to quota enforcement.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Officers (Class 1, Grade II) Service Recruitment Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Statutory basis for quota determination; binding on government.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed in part: Seniority and promotion rules upheld as constitutional; quota rule binding, excess promotees illegal. Mandamus issued to respondents 1-3 to readjust seniority lists for 1951-1956+ per quota, excluding permanent appointments to Asst. Commissioners. Suggest roster system for future. No costs.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ of mandamus for fresh seniority list after quota adjustment; similar relief in Writ Petition No. 5/1966.

key_quotes.text: "The absence of arbitrary power is the first essential of the rule of law upon which our whole constitutional system is based."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes limits on executive discretion in quota application.

key_quotes.text: "A rule which gives seniority to outstanding officers with considerable experience... cannot per se be regarded as unreasonable."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Having fixed the quota... there is no discretion left with the Government of India to alter that quota... at its own will and pleasure."
key_quotes.speaker: court
